Art. 4.243. 
Authorised inheritance agreements 
Agreements or stipulations for valuable consideration are always authorised if they are entered into or made on a private basis, even if they concern the future succession of a party and even if that party reserves the right to dispose of the subject matter of the agreement or stipulation during his lifetime. An agreement or stipulation is by particular title where the agreement or stipulation does not concern the universality of the property which the party will leave on his death, or a share of the property which the party will leave on his death, or all his immovable property or all his movable property, or a share of all his immovable property or all his movable property on his death.
Sections 4.249 to 4.253 do not apply to the agreements as to succession referred to in this section.
